repnme.cdata!: Nepal - Cottage and Small Industries Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Cottage and Small
            Industries Project for Nepal was good. The project achieved
            its lending component objectives satisfactorily with most of
            its quantitative targets being either achieved or surpassed.
            Its impact has been substantial, sustainability is likely,
            and both the Bank and Borrower acted satisfactorily. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, effective
            appraisal procedures, intensive supervision, and enforcement
            of credit discipline in the repayment of sub loans and the
            institutionalization of a credit guarantee scheme are
            important elements in successful project-based lending.
            Second, measures have to be taken to compel credit
            discipline among large sub-borrowers, including the
            requirement and enforcement of partial securities and
            circulating a list of defaulters to all PCI branches. Third,
            in the export development component, more time than
            anticipated was needed to resolve the material supply,
            product design, and marketing problems limiting export
            expansion. Lastly, CIDB needs to evolve its approach to
            training by providing substantial training to trainers to
            enable them to upgrade the skills of existing artisans. The
            upgrading of skills should be based on local sustained
            demand for consumer products.

repnme.cdata!: Nepal - Cottage and Small Industries Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project aims to generate employment,
            raise incomes and increase foreign exchange earnings through
            expanded production and exports of cottage and small
            industry products. The project would upgrade private and
            public sector technical, marketing, and credit services and
            redirect Government incentives affecting the cottage and
            small industry sector. As a first phase program, the project
            would focus on the Kathmandu Valley and the Gandaki Zone,
            testing, developing and improving the various institutions
            and services. By clarifying the responsibilities of the
            various agencies, including an expanded role for the private
            sector, and providing significant technical assistance and
            training, the project would reduce the risks associated with
            undertaking such multi-component ventures. Each component
            includes a strong monitoring and evaluation system, which
            should facilitate response and corrective action in the face
            of unforeseen difficulties.

docna.cdata!: Nepal - Cottage and Small Industries Project
